title: How to even write a song - Making Hit Records - Quora

response.answer_text: ORIGINAL QUESTION: How do you even write a song? Usually, my "songs" are about 2-3 paragraphs long and I know that's not enough to make it a song. I'm just starting off with my first EP and I want to release a FULL album but not with songs that are 2-3 paragraphs long. Songs don’t usually have “paragraphs”. They have “verses”, usually a “chorus”, and sometimes a “bridge”. Occasionally, they may even have a “refrain”. So, you may have more “song” in front of you than you realize. Choruses are oftentimes repeated after each verse, so you may have even more song in front of you still. It’s just a matter of how you work it. Generally, a song tells a story. One way to get the ball rolling on that, is simply to write out the story in your own words, ignoring “verse” and “rhyme” and “meter”, just tell the story any old way, just like you were telling a story to a friend. Write that down like this: A long time ago, I knew this guy in Louisiana who was a really good guitar player. He wasn’t the brightest bulb in the box and really could barely even read or write, but he sure could play guitar. He was a country boy and lived in the woods in an actual log cabin believe it or not. This guy played guitar so well that people would come from miles around to hear him play. He was that good. Sometimes, he played so well, that those listening would be overcome with emotion and start shouting, “Go! Go!” That’s how good he was. He was so poor he couldn’t afford a guitar case, so he just carried his guitar in a gunny sack, I kid you not. He would walk to town and sit down by the train station and, I swear to God, this kid picked up the rhythm of the old steam locomotives and used that like a backing-track for his guitar playing. It was amazing! Word of his skill on guitar spread and pretty soon, he started drawing a pretty fair size crowd. The people in the crowd would nearly always be swept away by the emotion of his playing and soon the habit of shouting “Go! Go!” had spread far and wide. His mother, recognizing his unusual talent, told him that someday, he was going to be a really famous band-leader, with his name in lights. Now you have a story. So it’s time to hammer the story into song form. Here’s what that might look like → (The first verse): Deep down in Louisiana close to New OrleansWay back up in the woods among the evergreensThere stood a log cabin made of earth and woodWhere lived a country boy named MaxwellWho never ever learned to read or write so wellBut he could play a guitar just like a ringing a bell So we have “Maxwell” which is my friend’s name, “so well” and, “a bell” so far. Pretty clever, don’t you think? Now we need to write the “hook”. The “hook” is the part that everyone will remember even if they’ve only ever heard the song one time. So, it has to be catchy, simple and easy to remember. I’m going to use what the crowd used to shout at my friend. So let’s try that: Go! Go! Maxwell go! Go! Go! Maxwell go! So, not bad. But “Maxwell” is hard to pronounce and makes the whole phrase clumsy. So, even though that’s my friend’s name, and even though it’s going to ruin my cute three-rhyme thing in the verse, I’m going to change it to “Johnny” cuz that’s easier to say. And I’m going to change the phrasing because the way it is now sounds more like a football cheer than a song. So, let’s fix that part and try again: Go! Go! Go, Johnny Go! Go! Go, Johnny Go, go, go! Go Johnny go! Go! Go! Johnny Go! Go! Johnny B. Goode! So, I added a last name and middle initial too, in such a way that now, it’s not just a name, it’s an admonition! That should make it even more memorable! And the whole chorus is only two words repeated over and over. Easy! Everyone should be able to remember that, right? So now, I have my first verse and my chorus. The bridge and refrain aren’t mandatory and so, since this is my first song ever, I’m going to leave those out. Maybe on the next song, I’ll try adding them in, but for now, I’m sticking with verse and chorus and maybe a guitar solo in there somewhere. So, for the music, I’m going to keep it simple. I’m using that “locomotive” rhythm with a simple I, IV, V chord progression (don’t worry about the chords for now, as that has to do with another concept called “music theory” which we will go into on another post. But just remember, we’re going to use the “one” chord, the “four” chord, and the “five” chord in this song. There are about a million or more songs that use those three chords, so we’re in good company there. We use numbers instead of letters for the chords, so that, in case we need to change keys for some reason, no one gets confused. One, four and five are always the same no matter what key we’re playing in. Here is what all that might sound like once we put it all together:  Not too bad, eh? This isn’t the “original” version of this song, but it’s a very good version that I think illustrates some important points in songwriting. You did great in your first songwriting effort! Now go forth and write! (NOTE: This song was actually written a long time ago by the late, great Chuck Berry Chuck Berry - Wikipedia. It is one of the most memorable and often-performed songs in all of Rock’n’Roll history, and a sterling example of how to write a song.)

-You know I think that Less Equals More works pretty good on Original Lyrics.Some of the Best Rock Songs I have heard sometimes use less than a paragraph of words. I believe the master of the paragraph song was (Sadly) Scott Weiland of Stone Temple Pilots , and Velvet Revolver. He very creatively would sing maybe half to three quarters of his paragraph,, THEN USE HIS REMAINING WORDS IN A REPEATING FASHION. AND YOU KNOW WHAT? Most of the time you or anyone never noticed unless you were writing down the words to maybe perform or record that tune! Don’t be down on yourself because you ONLY wrote a paragraph. Be thankful for every little transmission of creativity you receive. And be creative with HOW you use your “Transmissions.” I will usually “Write” either “Half”or a “Complete” sheet of paper, envelope , Napkin, or whatever.And all my stuff is what I call “Stream of the flow of UN-Consciousness” And it looks pretty good right after I do it. But a couple of days later……uh man. I usually find that I MAYBE at most have one, maybe two good ideas on that paper. And if I try to go back a day or two later and fix it, Nope I am too invested in it, and lack the restraint, or discipline to make Major changes that NEED to be made to it to make it flow or work. But if every time I write lyrics , AND WHEN I GET DONE WRITING, THE PIECE OF PAPER GOES IN ONE OF TWO OFFICE TYPE FILING CABINETS. You would be amazed how quickly pages start stacking up when you write regularly, and often. So now when I have an idea, or want to work on an idea, I go to the drawer and start pulling out sheets of paper with lyrics. And Nine Times Out of Ten, I will find something that blends nicely with what I am doing, Or something I wrote a ways back, That I don’t have ANY TROUBLE SNIPPING IT INTO LITTLE BITS SO MAYBE I USE IT ON FOUR OR FIVE DIFFERENT IDEAS. Maybe go on youtube and look up the Stone Temple Pilots band’s channel, and i would recommend Core, Tiny Music From The Vatican, and PURPLE. ALL great albums/CD’s in their own write. But Get them back to your “Evil” Laboratory for a little dissection. Check out the creative way he used just the barest of lyrics on some songs and you will be amazed! And then you can Amaze your friends and then their Friends until you AMAZINGLY get your ass kicked! No, just kidding. Be humble, and Thankful for every tidbit you DO receive, because…………(Some people DON’T get ANY kind of creativity or inspiration AT ALL! Or they are just too insensitive to realize they are being gifted!) And don’t be so serious or demanding on your self. I have actually heard recording artists (Bands) who recorded songs that after intense scrutiny, They could not come up with like one or two lines of prose, and instead of maybe turning up the faders on guitar or bass to make the spot not so noticeable, Instead elected to just sing “Mush” or “Unintelligible Garbage” into the microphone on a “Big Corporation Sponsored “ record. The Red Hot Chili Peppers come to mind in that category..

‘How do you even write a song? Usually, my "songs" are about 2-3 paragraphs long and I know that's not enough to make it a song. I'm just starting off with my first EP and I want to release a FULL album but not with songs that are 2-3 paragraphs long.’ You're trying to write exactly one album? That's not how the industry does it. If you want an album of 8-10 songs, you should intentionally write at least 20, then start narrowing down the choices. Don't limit your creativity by volume. The lucky album makers have “unreleased” and “B-side” gems that surface after the album gets released.
